awd_titl_txt: The Kompaneets Equation, Anomalous Diffusion, and Brownian Entanglement
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project is devoted to mathematical study of questions arising in the investigation of three natural phenomena; these studies are united by the use of related mathematical tools. The first set of questions concerns mathematically understanding behavior of photons in low-density plasmas. The second set of questions concerns the behavior of particles in fluid flow. In certain situations important for applications, particles diffuse in unusual ways.  This project investigates such "anomalous" diffusive behavior on intermediate (as opposed to long) time scales. The third set of questions is motivated by mathematically quantifying the entanglement of long polymer molecules; it aims to quantify the winding of trajectories of the related random walks. Each of these research projects involves graduate students and postdoctoral associates, who will be broadly trained through the course of their work. 

This research will use tools from applied analysis, partial differential equations, and probability. The first set of questions concerns the long-time behavior of the Kompaneets equation, and focuses on understanding the formation of a Bose-Einstein condensate. The second set of questions studies the small-noise limit of passive scalar transport and other related models arising in the context of fluids. While the long-time behavior of these equations is well known, here interest is in the small-noise intermediate-time regime where an anomalous diffusive effect is observed, and the limiting behavior is described by a time changed Brownian motion and time-fractional equations. The third set of questions studies the long-time "winding" or "entanglement" of Brownian trajectories on compact Riemannian manifolds with boundary. This is closely related to heat kernel estimates on covering spaces, and is motivated by the study of the entanglement of long polymer molecules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project produced various results concerning anomalous diffusion, mixing and enhanced dissipation, anomalous dissipation, Bose–Einstein condensation and global dynamics of the Kompaneets equation.

Global Dynamics of the Kompaneets Equation. The Kompaneets equation governs the dynamics of the photon energy spectrum in high temperature plasmas. One fundamental and challenging problem is to understand the long time dynamics. Formally, the total photon number is conserved; however the stationary solutions (Bose–Einstein statistics) do not support configurations with a large photon number. As a result, there is an accumulation of photons at the zero energy state, which corresponds to the formation of a Bose–Einstein condensate. Results from this grant prove this rigorously in certain scenarios and completely describe the long time dynamics.

Enhanced Dissipation and singularity suppression. Diffusion and mixing are two fundamental phenomena that arise in a wide variety of applications ranging from micro-fluids to meteorology, and even cosmology. In incompressible fluids, stirring induces mixing by filamentation and facilitates the formation of small scales. Diffusion, on the other hand, efficiently damps small scales and the balance between these two phenomena leads to enhanced dissipation – the tendency of solutions to dissipate energy faster than normal.

Results from this grant provide criterion characterizing and quantifying enhanced dissipation, and applications to the study of nonlinear problems. For instance, in many situations the evolution of the population density of bacterial colony is often governed by two competing effects: diffusion, which causes the population density to spread out and chemo-attraction which causes the population density to concentrate in certain regions. If the chemo-attraction is stronger, it can lead to a “population explosion”, or a singularity in the population density. The results from this grant show that this singularity can be avoided if the ambient fluid is stirred by a velocity field that sufficiently enhances dissipation. Similar results are proved in the context of phase separation, and quenching of reactions.

Anomalous Dissipation. In certain turbulent regimes fluids are expected to dissipate energy at a rate independent of the kinematic viscosity. While this is a longstanding conjecture, it is not yet been rigorously proved. Results from this grant provide a first example of a velocity field that rigorously exhibits the anomalous diffusive behavior. While this does not yet address the problem of anomalous dissipation in the nonlinear setting of incompressible fluids, it is a first step in this direction.

Broader Impact. One component of the broader impact is in the training of students and postdocs, contributing to an increase in the technically trained workforce. As part of their training, the students and post-docs produced excellent masters thesis, Ph.D. thesis and publications in peer-reviewed journals. Upon completion of their degrees / post-doctoral work, the trainees secured excellent positions both in academia and in the industry.

Another component of the broader impact is to the larger scientific community. Results from this grant mathematically characterize the long time dynamics of the Kompaneets equation. This has applications to modern cosmology, where the Kompaneets equation plays an important and fundamental role. Enhanced and anomalous dissipation play an essential role in the study of fluid dynamics and turbulence, and the results from this grant have many applications to these areas.
